body:
What a mess!
Thanks for pointing this out, @bethrice44!

It would appear that the slicing behaviour is inconsistent when you compare datetime indexing to `iloc` indexing!
Compare this to `y[:5]` vs `y[5:]`, in which the split is non-overlapping.

I think there is a deeper problem here, with `pandas`, where this should be raised if it hasn't already been.

On the `sktime` side, we probably need to deal with this by case distinction in the slicing logic.
I confirm the issue on python 3.8 and windows, current `main`.

> What a mess! Thanks for pointing this out, @bethrice44!
> 
> It would appear that the slicing behaviour is inconsistent when you compare datetime indexing to `iloc` indexing! Compare this to `y[:5]` vs `y[5:]`, in which the split is non-overlapping.
> 
> I think there is a deeper problem here, with `pandas`, where this should be raised if it hasn't already been.
> 
> On the `sktime` side, we probably need to deal with this by case distinction in the slicing logic.

On pandas, an [issue](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/36548) was raised, but it is apparently the documented behaviour, so no fix. 

> @IainStrachan this is the documented behaviour. Slicing with integers is positional indexing (see https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#slicing-ranges), while slicing with timestamps is using the labels. And then see here (https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#selection-by-label, the first paragraph after the three warning boxes) saying that label-based indexing includes both start and end point.

Could use something like this to check? 
```
        for id in y_index:
            forecaster = clone(forecaster)
            y_train = y[:id]  # subset on which we fit
            X_train = X[:id]
            y_test = y[id:]
            X_test = X[id:]
            if y_train.max() == y_test.min():
                y_test = y_test[1:]  # subset on which we predict
                X_test = X_test[1:]
```

Fixed in [this PR](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2706) for `ConformalIntervals` using a new `get_slice` utility function which incorporates the conditional logic for timestamp/ period and integer indexes. The same logic can be used here once that PR is merged.

yes - as you proposed on slack, @bethrice44, `NaiveVariance` could (and probably should) be fixed the same way, i.e., using `get_slice` to ensure correct behaviour, conditional on whether indexing is by int or by time stamp.

issue.title: [ENH] Add support to get_slice for multi-index and hierarchical data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is.

In order to deal with [this issue ](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2702), a function called `get_slice` has been created [here](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2706) so slicing objects is always inclusive at the start and exclusive at the end. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
As in `get_window` ([link](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/a761368f32b12913f2d7c22d87776e6112cc785d/sktime/datatypes/_utilities.py#L222)) we need to add some additional conditional logic to deal with multi-index and hierarchical data structures. 

We should also expand the tests in [datatypes/tests/test_utils.py](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/datatypes/tests/test_utils.py) to cover these cases.

issue.title: [BUG] Fixing overlap in `NaiveVariance` train/test set due to inclusive indexing for timestamp limits

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Issue #2702

Pandas treats slicing with integer vs timestamp index / period index differently (the first has an exclusive end and the second inclusive). `get_slice` ensures both are exclusive.

body: PR [here](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2760) to fix this as described in comment.
